Web scrapping from IMDB using Python

June 30, 2015

Recently I worked on the project requiring me to scrap top 10 movies names from IMDB/boxoffice and the name of charachters in each movie.

I have used lxml package because it support xpath. In case you don’t know about Xpath, you can easily learn from here. You can use other packages too. Basic idea of this blog is to make approach as simple as possible.

 1 from lxml import html
 2 import requests
 3 
 4 def box_office(n):         			# "n" is top n movies on the page remember "n" should always less than 10, as there is only 
 5 									# 10 movies listed on http://www.imdb.com/boxoffice/ 
 6 	page = requests.get('http://www.imdb.com/boxoffice/')
 7 	tree = html.fromstring(page.text)
 8 	path = tree.xpath('//tbody/tr/td[3]/a')
 9 	movie = []
10 	url = []
11 
12 	for i in range(0 , n):
13 		link = path[i]
14 		movie.append(link.text)
15 		url.append("http://www.imdb.com"+ link.attrib.get('href'))
16 	return movie, url

The above code will return two list for box_office(5): movie names:['Jurassic World', 'Inside Out', 'Terminator Genisys', 'Magic Mike XXL', 'Ted 2'] url of movies: ['http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0369610/', 'http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2096673/', 'http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1340138/', 'http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2268016/', 'http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2637276/']

Scrap cast name from above url.

 1 from lxml import html
 2 import requests
 3 
 4 def cast(url):
 5 	page_url = requests.get(url)
 6 	tree_url = html.fromstring(page_url.text)
 7 
 8 	path_url_odd = tree_url.xpath('//tr[@class="odd"]/td[2]/a/span')
 9 	path_url_even = tree_url.xpath('//tr[@class="even"]/td[2]/a/span')
10 
11 	cast = []
12 
13 	for i in range(0,len(path_url_odd)):
14 		try:
15 			cast.append(path_url_odd[i].text)
16 			cast.append(path_url_even[i].text)
17 		except IndexError:
18 			continue
19 	return cast

The above code will going to return list of names of cast in the movie.

for cast("http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0369610/") it will return: ['Chris Pratt', 'Bryce Dallas Howard', 'Irrfan Khan', "Vincent D'Onofrio", 'Ty Simpkins', 'Nick Robinson', 'Jake Johnson', 'Omar Sy', 'BD Wong', 'Judy Greer', 'Lauren Lapkus', 'Brian Tee', 'Katie McGrath', 'Andy Buckley', 'Eric Edelstein']

Combining above peice of code into final working program.

 1 from lxml import html
 2 import requests
 3 
 4 
 5 ###############################################################################################################
 6 # 						Actual function which is to be call
 7 #				NOTE: Value of "n" should be less than 10 because onle 10 movies list is there on "http://www.imdb.com/boxoffice/"
 8 def box_office(n):
 9 	page = requests.get('http://www.imdb.com/boxoffice/')
10 	tree = html.fromstring(page.text)
11 
12 	path = tree.xpath('//tbody/tr/td[3]/a')
13 
14 	movie = []
15 	movie_cast = []
16 
17 
18 	for i in range(0 , n):
19 		link = path[i]
20 		movie.append(link.text)
21 		movie_cast.append(cast("http://www.imdb.com"+ link.attrib.get('href')))
22 	return (movie , movie_cast)
23 
24 ###########################################################################################################
25 #					cast function scrab cast of particular movie, It takes url as argument
26 
27 def cast(url):
28 	page_url = requests.get(url)
29 	tree_url = html.fromstring(page_url.text)
30 
31 	path_url_odd = tree_url.xpath('//tr[@class="odd"]/td[2]/a/span')
32 	path_url_even = tree_url.xpath('//tr[@class="even"]/td[2]/a/span')
33 
34 	cast = []
35 
36 	for i in range(0,len(path_url_odd)):
37 		try:
38 			cast.append(path_url_odd[i].text)
39 			cast.append(path_url_even[i].text)
40 		except IndexError:
41 			continue
42 	return cast

Now call box_office() it will return two list, one containing movie name on boxoffice page and other containing name of cast of that movie.

comment below for any type of typo, or suggestion.
